Award.AwardTitle: RAPID/Collaborative Research: Field Study of Volunteer Convergence in Post-Disaster Relief

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The emergency response to Hurricane Harvey involved not only traditional relief agencies but many ordinary citizens and small groups who felt compelled to assist the many residents who found themselves stranded in the face of rising flood waters. Many volunteers brought personal watercraft and organized rescue missions along flooded streets and bayous. Other groups, such as religious organizations, small businesses, and service organizations, opened their doors as informal shelters, with the congregations or organization members serving as volunteers and providing food and shelter for displaced individuals. These spontaneous volunteers represent a valuable source of labor but present significant logistical challenges for central response planners. The spontaneous volunteer labor force is largely unpredictable, may enter and leave at will, and possess a variety of useful skills. Moreover, while individuals may have good intentions in volunteering, they are largely untrained in emergency response and may present dangers to themselves and to others. This RAPID award will provide a better understanding of the dynamics of spontaneous volunteer response and should improve the ability of response planners to effectively incorporate citizen volunteers in disaster relief efforts. A graduate student and undergraduate students will be involved in this effort and will be provided valuable experience by working on this research project.

This award will provide support for data collection efforts in Houston, Texas in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey with several research objectives in mind: (1) to understand the organizational dynamics associated with volunteer intake and assignment; (2) to create and validate analytical models for volunteer intake and service length; (3) to understand the barriers to successful incorporation of spontaneous volunteers into the emergency response to disasters. The PIs will collect data from a number of groups involved in the relief effort, including religious organizations, local businesses, ad-hoc groups, and traditional relief agencies. The PIs will observe activities in active relief operations, interview relief staff and volunteers, and collect and analyze volunteer logs and disaster management systems. These data will provide valuable input for predictive models for volunteer convergence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this RAPID award was to provide a better understanding of the dynamics of spontaneous volunteer response to improve the ability of response planners to effectively incorporate citizen volunteers in disaster relief efforts.

Intellectual Merit:  This project collected data related to volunteer convergence that is rarely observed and gathered in post disaster relief. Spontaneous volunteers are understudied in the disaster management lierature even though they are a growing phenomenon.  This data included observations of activities conducted by volunteers during active relief operations, interviews with relief staff and volunteers, and data collected from volunteer logs and disaster management systems.

Broder Impact: As natural disasters are increasing in both frequency and intensity, the importance of understanding how to best utilize human resources during post-disaster relief is only increasing. People are often motivated to assist in post-disaster relief efforts; however, they often do not know how they can help. Some organizations are overwhelmed with volunteers and turn people away, while some organizations are underwhelmed and are in desperate need of volunteers. This project will continue the conversation of volunteer management, which in the long run will save lives and resources through more efficient use of volunteers.  In addition, eight undergraduate students were involved in research.  They were exposed to qualitative research, which is uncommon for engineering students and interacted with non-profits and the community.

Summary of Outcomes: Eleven total interviews were conducted and transcribed from both spontaneous volunteers and spontaneous volunteer coordinators. Both qualitative and quantitative analysis was then performed on the transcriptions, and process maps were developed to better understand the variety in approaches to post-disaster relief efforts. Thematic Content Analysis was performed in NVivo, a qualitative analysis software. The volunteer themes were broken down into seven different nodes: how a volunteer discovered an organization, how volunteers were recruited, the motivation for volunteering, the number of volunteers over time, problems experienced by volunteers, the sites overarching problems, and the role of social media for volunteers. Similarly, the process/organizational themes were separated into seven different nodes: ideas for improvement, volunteer skill level, assigned task upon arrival, roles of children or special need volunteers, services provided in the processes, information about the volunteers and tracking their hours, and the sign up process. These themes can be utilized in future efforts to identify the best areas to focus on when learning more about volunteer efforts.

In addition to qualitative analysis in NVivo, quantitative analysis was performed on the transcriptions with SAS Enterprise Miner to transform unstructured data to structured data for use in further analysis. Sentiment analysis rules were created specifically to disaster response terms, which can be applied by organizations to analyze their volunteer satisfaction and improve their volunteer management.

Furthermore, process maps were created of several disaster relief operations, with their similarities and differences notes.  Data was collected from a relief center regarding volunteer arrival and service.  These results inform quantitative models that can be used to improve volunteer management suggestions offered by the operations research community.

While this project focused primarily on Hurricane Harvey, this methodology can be extended to any type of disaster both beyond hurricanes and beyond 2017.
